title: TLS Version Intolerance
author: Hanno Böck
abstract: In a TLS handshake, the client announces it's maximum supported version and the server then has to pick the version given this and its own level of support. TLS Version Intolerance refers to a widespread bug that many server implementations abort the connection when the client version is higher than the highest version number they support. This, in turn leads to clients downgrading voluntarily when experiencing connection failures.

title: Taint me if you can
author: joernchen
abstract:
Tainting in Ruby is often seen as a security feature. This short talk will show some quite funny cornercases where tainting fails. We well see how CVE-2015-7551 can be re-introduced. Also an old MSF module from 2011 [0] will be reanimted to work in 2016.


 [0] https://github.com/rapid7/metasploit-framework/blob/master/modules/exploits/linux/misc/drb_remote_codeexec.rb
